title: How to Pop a Water Bottle Manually

steps.headline: Get an empty plastic water bottle, preferably an Ozarka water bottle, or around that size (preferably the cheapest bottle there is).
steps.description: Go to your local grocery store and pick up some store-brand bottled water, those usually work well. The reason for this is bottles from Aquafina, Dasani, and other name brands have thicker plastic, making Step 2 harder.

steps.headline: Twist the bottle in the center or at the top of the bottom third of the bottle.
Once you have twisted it as far as you can, carefully twist the cap loose, but not fully, and, holding the bottle securely, slide the cap around slowly with one finger until it pops off loudly.
steps.description:
Often, the bottle will emit white vapor, caused by the water droplets inside the bottle evaporating from the quick pressure change. It is not dangerous to sniff it, if one is so inclined. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/62\/Pop-a-Water-Bottle-Manually-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Pop-a-Water-Bottle-Manually-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/62\/Pop-a-Water-Bottle-Manually-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Pop-a-Water-Bottle-Manually-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Find a suitable plastic water bottle.
steps.description: Empty it of water and securely close the cap.

tyn: Cheap water bottle with thin plastic
text:
Bottle twist Get an empty plastic water bottle, preferably an Ozarka water bottle, or around that size (preferably the cheapest bottle there is). Go to your local grocery store and pick up some store-brand bottled water, those usually work well. The reason for this is bottles from Aquafina, Dasani, and other name brands have thicker plastic, making Step 2 harder. Twist the bottle in the center or at the top of the bottom third of the bottle. Once you have twisted it as far as you can, carefully twist the cap loose, but not fully, and, holding the bottle securely, slide the cap around slowly with one finger until it pops off loudly. Often, the bottle will emit white vapor, caused by the water droplets inside the bottle evaporating from the quick pressure change. It is not dangerous to sniff it, if one is so inclined. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/62\/Pop-a-Water-Bottle-Manually-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Pop-a-Water-Bottle-Manually-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/62\/Pop-a-Water-Bottle-Manually-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Pop-a-Water-Bottle-Manually-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Step and open Find a suitable plastic water bottle. Empty it of water and securely close the cap. Step on the bottle. Open the bottle cap slightly. Watch it fly away.
sentences: Bottle twist Get an empty plastic water bottle, preferably an Ozarka water bottle, or around that size (preferably the cheapest bottle there is).
Go to your local grocery store and pick up some store-brand bottled water, those usually work well.
The reason for this is bottles from Aquafina, Dasani, and other name brands have thicker plastic, making Step 2 harder.
Twist the bottle in the center or at the top of the bottom third of the bottle.
Once you have twisted it as far as you can, carefully twist the cap loose, but not fully, and, holding the bottle securely, slide the cap around slowly with one finger until it pops off loudly.
Often, the bottle will emit white vapor, caused by the water droplets inside the bottle evaporating from the quick pressure change.
It is not dangerous to sniff it, if one is so inclined.

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Step and open Find a suitable plastic water bottle.
Empty it of water and securely close the cap.
